title: What is the song “Bad” about by U2? - Quora

response.answer_text: The hours I spent playing this song when I was a teenage bass player in a garage band. Hours. I don’t like U2, but I concede that ‘Bad’ has a certain gawky, two-chord grandeur which can be very effective. (It actually has four chords: two of them are reserved for a moment of maximum drama.) I believe the general consensus among the U2 community is that ‘Bad’ is about heroin addiction, which in the mid-80s was quite a scourge in U2’s stomping ground of north Dublin. Beyond that, it’s deliberately vague, but in 80s rock generally, it’s an interesting moment of rare compassion. Let’s do a commentary, shall we? If you twist and turn away. If you tear yourself in two again. There’s a singer, and there’s a ‘you’, and I believe the song constructs the singer as the observer, the ‘you’ as a friend or lover who is an addict. If I could, yes I would, If I could, I would let it go. The singer empathises with ‘your’ desire to ‘let it go’, but whether this means letting of life or of drugs is left ambiguous. Surrender, dislocate. This sounds to me like a warning: If you surrender, you will ‘dis-locate’—leave the world you’re in, become broken. If I could throw this lifeless life-line to the wind. This line is rather too pleased with its own mysteriousness, but I think the meaning becomes clear from the succeeding lines. Leave this heart of clay, see you walk, walk away Into the night, and through the rain Into the half light and through the flame. If I could, through myself, set your spirit free I'd lead your heart away, see you break, break away Into the light and to the day. In other words, the singer wants to be able to free ‘you’ from the addiction ‘through myself’, so that the person will no longer be in such torment. I don’t think this bit is about dying: I think it’s about getting clean, but it’s ambiguous enough (‘set your spirit free’, ‘into the light’ etc.) that it could also be about death being the release from pain. To let it go and so to find away. To let it go and so find away. I'm wide awake. This is the point in the song where it builds to its first big turgid climax, the music boiling up underneath Bono’s full-throated yelling: the way he sings ‘find away-ay-ay’ makes it sound like he’s weeping. ‘I’m wide awake’ is the singer keeping some sort of vigil at the side of the junkie, I think. I'm wide awake, wide awake. I'm not sleeping. This is the bit where the poor bass player (fourteen-year-old me) gets to stop rocking back and forth between A and D and finally goes up to G, then down to E, D and A again. The addict in the song is perhaps weathering a crisis. If you should ask, then maybe They'd tell you what I would say True colours fly in blue and black Blue silken sky and burning flag. Colours crash, collide in blood-shot eyes. Yeah…not sure what this is about, unless it’s Bono getting all poetic about track-marks and the visible signs of heroin addiction. If I could, you know I wouldIf I could, I would let it go. Now comes the instrumental bit, in which The Edge leans into his delay pedal. This desperation, dislocation Separation, condemnation Revelation, in temptation Isolation, desolation In performance, our singer, a dedicated U2 fan, would almost always keep this going a bit longer with Masturbation, constipation, railway station, urination and anything else he could think of. Let it go and so to find awayTo let it go and so to find away To let it go and so to find away I'm wide awake, I'm wide awake, wide awake I'm not sleeping Oh no, no, no. And so the tumescent music finally dies down and goes ping-y again, and the light dawns over the tower blocks and the addict is either dead or…y’know, not. So, that, I think, is the sound of ‘Bad’. In a sense, it’s U2’s ‘TB Sheets’: a harrowed meditation at the bedside of a sick loved one. That said, Bono in 2011 informed a Pittsburgh audience that the song was written for ‘a very special man’ who was actually at the concert. The man in question was Andy Rowen, brother of Peter Rowen, the kid on the cover of Boy and War. Andy Rowen was in Parnell Street, Dublin in 1974 when a bomb planted by loyalist terrorists went off nearby. He was eleven years old at the time, and the resulting PTSD caused him to have all sorts of substance abuse issues in later life. He survived, however, and when last heard was living in the USA and had found Jesus.  Make of that what you will. (Sources: ANDY ROWEN'S STORY Bad (U2 song) - Wikipedia)
